results.title: Don't Think I Don't Think
results.brief_description: Documents an important conference on rights for the disabled held at Melbourne University in 1981. The disabled groups present drew up a charter of rights- rights to work, to live in their own houses etc. free of the constraints that paternalistic institutions impose

results.title: Blokes and sheds
results.creator_credit: Sarah Wishart, Robi Watt, Mark Thomson, Australian Film Commission, South Australian Film Corporation and SBS Independent
results.brief_description:
The backyard shed is an Australian icon. It may appear, to the unenlightened, to be a tacked-together corrugated iron structure full of junk, nails and spiders. In truth, it has become a peculiarly Australian horde of stories and myths about isolation, masculinity, identity, capability, self esteem, tradition and even passionate obsession. It is history on a very human scale, a one-person size record of a life. There is a mystery to a shed, with dark corners; yet grace, too in odd and unexpected ways. By talking to the owners and occupiers of twelve vastly diverse sheds all over South Australia, ‘Blokes and Sheds’ casts a gentle enquiring light into those cobwebbed nooks and crannies to tease out many paradoxes and passions. Each shed is the setting for its owner to open their hearts and share their stories in these twelve, two-minute documentaries.
Based on the book by Mark Thomson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sarah Wishart, Robi Watt, Mark Thomson, Australian Film Commission, South Australian Film Corporation and SBS Independent

results.title: The Boy from Taurianova
results.brief_description: Rocco arrived from Calabria in 1962 at the age of 19 and immediately started his working life on a potato farm in Ballarat. He lovingly dedicates this story of his life to his daughter Connie. Created as part of the Racconti: La Voce del Popolo Digital Storytelling in association with The Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF).

results.title: David Bowie is becoming a Medium
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description: Speaking to the BBC in 1976, Bowie claimed that his career was built on the desire to “be the instigator of new ideas….to turn people on to new things and new perspectives…to be that sort of catalytic kind of thing.“ He described rock music as a medium through which he could achieve this impact and speculated that he would move from using rock in this way to becoming a medium himself, saying, “hopefully that’ll happen one day…that’s really why I do it…to become a medium.” This talk takes Bowie’s characteristically self-aware and oblique statement as a starting point for an exploration of his extraordinary creative impact and cultural status. Sharing insights gained during the making of ‘David Bowie is’ at the V&A, it explains how the exhibition was devised to perpetuate the catalytic and inspirational power of Bowie’s art, style and music. Presented by Dr Kathryn Johnson, Assistant Curator for the ‘David Bowie is’ Exhibition from the V&A Museum.

results.title: How AI sees me
results.brief_description: All those videogame and anime-inspired avatars you’re seeing on social media aren’t as innocent as they look. After uploading selfies and paying a small fee, the Lansa app can turn users into fairy princesses and rugged adventurers. But the AI-generated artworks are trained on the work of actual artists, some of whom fear their creativity will be replaced by computers. Non-White users have also reported that the app anglicised their features, while at other times it’s created sexualised images from pictures of children. Not to mention some believe that users are paying to train facial recognition intelligence and give up their personal data. So, look before you Lansa.
results.description: All those videogame and anime-inspired avatars you’re seeing on social media aren’t as innocent as they look. After uploading selfies and paying a small fee, the Lensa app can turn users into fairy princesses and rugged adventurers. Not to mention some believe that users are paying to train facial recognition intelligence and giving up their personal data. So, look before you Lensa.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Red Desert Render
results.brief_description:
The world of Rockstar Game’s Red Dead Redemption 2 is meticulously crafted. Not only are its environments rendered in stunning detail, but it’s designed to keep players interested and engaged. Like a theme park, it has waypoints, landmarks, maps – design features that encourage the player to explore the game and its narrative without feeling lost.
By contrast, award-winning game designer, Ian MacLarty describes the vast expanses that exist out of bounds as feeling transgressive, surprising and impermanent – a piece of genuine digital wilderness, where the landscape responds unpredictably to player action. One wrong move could risk the player respawning within the map’s bounds and spending hours trying to break out again.
This was the experience MacLarty tried to replicate in Red Desert Render, a surreal open-world game that encourages curiosity and surprise. Its auto-generated landscapes are intentionally unstable – entering the ‘shop’ changes the shape of your avatar drastically, and swimming in a bath propels you into the sky, where you can swim through the air.
It represents a couple of turning points in MacLarty’s artistic practice: it’s his first open-world videogame and his first multiplayer online game. MacLarty has continued to refine the design principles we see in this work in the videogames he has made since, including his upcoming release Mars First Logistics.

Music by Sam Gill and Luke Neher. Sound design by Sam Gill. Starring Kalonica Quigley, Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, and friends. Voiceover is excerpted from an interview originally for P3 Spel, conducted by Angelica Norgren.

results.title: The Grannies
results.creator_credit: Luke Neher, Marie Foulston and Nick Murray
results.credit_line:
Music by Sam Gill and Luke Neher. Sound design by Sam Gill. Starring Kalonica Quigley, Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, and friends. Voiceover is excerpted from an interview originally for P3 Spel, conducted by Angelica Norgren.

Visuals captured from Red Dead Redemption 2
Rockstar Games, USA, 2018

Courtesy Marie Foulston
results.brief_description:
The Grannies follows a group of artistic game developers (Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, Kalonica Quigley and friends) as they find a way to go beyond the map while playing Red Dead Redemption 2 together. Styled as a kind of digital travelogue, the work uses screen-captured footage the artists took as they played, following their explorations of the unpredictable, procedurally generated landscapes outside the game world.
By exiting the bloodthirsty world of the Wild West frontier, these artists found an abstract, seemingly endless digital space where the building blocks of the game world itself were laid bare. Through their eyes, what might be seen as a glitch or a bug to another player becomes a set of artistic possibilities. Rather than focusing on the game’s objectives, their adventures beyond the map, and their reflections on them, are oriented around artistic inquiry, playfulness and friendship.
The unexpected terrain and landmarks the grannies discovered out of bounds don’t serve a story or game function. They only matter because they provoked curiosity and emotion in the people who found them – – not because they help direct players towards a goal.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Luke Neher, Marie Foulston and Nick Murray
results.description:
The Grannies follows a group of artistic game developers (Andrew Brophy, Marigold Bartlett, Ian MacLarty, Kalonica Quigley and friends) as they find a way to go beyond the map while playing Red Dead Redemption 2 together. Styled as a kind of digital travelogue, the work uses screen-captured footage the artists took as they played, following their explorations of the unpredictable, procedurally generated landscapes outside the game world.

By exiting the bloodthirsty world of the Wild West frontier, these artists found an abstract, seemingly endless digital space where the building blocks of the game were laid bare. Through their eyes, what might be seen as a glitch or a bug to another player piques curiosity about the materiality of the game’s environmental design. Textures collide at strange angles, revealing layers that are meant to be obscured. A strange grey cube hangs on the sky, monumental in its lack of finish and finesse compared to the landscape around it.

The unexpected terrain and landmarks The Grannies discovered out of bounds don’t serve a story or game function. They only matter because they provoked curiosity and emotion in the people who found them – not because they help direct players towards a goal.

These artists’ explorations are not just a way to escape the game’s map, but to escape the game’s expectations of how a player should act, and its methods of anticipating their actions.

results.title: Landmarks
results.credit_line:
Visuals captured by The Grannies from Red Dead Redemption 2
Rockstar Games, USA, 2018
Text by Kalonica Quigley
results.brief_description:
In their time out of bounds, The Grannies captured many landmarks and locations through Red Dead Redemption 2’s photography system.
Unlike many big-budget videogames, Red Dead Redemption 2 doesn’t offer a ‘photo mode’ that allows players to manipulate the time of day and camera angle. Instead, it operates more or less like a real-world camera, with each photo taken from the character’s perspective.
Ian MacLarty described lining up the perfect shot as ‘like a game in itself’, requiring a lifelike combination of precision and luck to capture the perfect angle and quality of light.
These photos, so lovingly framed and shot, have a radical undertone. Their explorations could be considered a kind of psychogeography – an artistic practice that involved exploring urban environments to emphasise personal responses to place, rather than focusing on productivity or purpose.
Similarly, the images captured here showcase The Grannies’ emotional, playful relationship with digital space that contradicts the intended design of the game.
Since they were taken, Red Dead Redemption 2 has been updated to stop players from travelling outside the map. Still, these images remain, a reminder of the freedom that curiosity and exploration can offer.
